snippet: Airstrikes have slowed the progress of Sunni militants laying siege to refugees on Mount Sinjar, but Pentagon officials also said that ISIS remained on the offense.
abstract: Pentagon officials say four days of airstrikes have slowed progress of Islamic State in Iraq and Syria militants laying siege to refugees on Mount Sinjar and advancing toward Kurdish capital of Erbil; officals say group remains strong and on the offense.

byline.original: By HELENE COOPER and ALISSA J. RUBIN
byline.contributor: Helene Cooper reported from Washington, and Alissa J. Rubin from Dohuk, Iraq. Michael R. Gordon contributed reporting from Sydney, Australia; Rod Nordland from Erbil, Iraq; and Mark Mazzetti from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Airstrikes have slowed the progress of Sunni militants laying siege to refugees on Mount Sinjar, but Pentagon officials also said that ISIS remained on the offense.

headline.main: Pentagon Says Airstrikes Have Slowed but Not Stopped Sunni Militants
headline.print_headline: Pentagon Says Airstrikes Have Slowed but Not Stopped Sunni Militants

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
